pros: Working on campus as a student might be challenging, but the staff at Rider's athletic department is second to none.
cons: Work management and balancing class work with a part-time job.

pros: there are no PhD or DMA students at WCC, so MM students get to be and the "top of the foodchain" of graduate students, compared to other programs where MM students can sometimes be treated like glorified undergrads. some professors will try to help you get published very early in your career as a contributing or co-author in journals or in their next book. but now WCC as we knew it (incl. the Princeton campus) is basically dead, doing your MM here is pretty much worthless, reputationally.
cons: WCC professors routinely exploit the goodwill of their most eager students and push them to the breaking point, and turn around and cast blame on everyone but themselves (be it trying to shift blame onto colleagues, other students, etc.). none of the work or network I did her has ever translated into meaningful professional opportunities in either teaching or arts management. certain staff members (performance management in particular) would routinely make racist comments about international students behind their backs, often within earshot of several other students, and would try to undermine them, particularly to undergrads. staff and professors alike would also often develop highly inappropriately close friendships with specific graduate students that created major power imbalances, favoritism, and streams of inappropriate gossip in every part of WCC.

pros: Allow for independence, Faculty are supportive of one another and very collegial. .Great benefits for employee (adding spouse and children are costly). Beautiful small campus, great students, involved and talented faculty.
cons: Admin and Faculty are at odds a lot of the time. Union goes to bat for faculty and negotiates for everyone - which is good. Pressure to get enrollment in the college is stressful. Like most colleges today- lower enrollments are the cause of many issues. There is a deep divide between faculty and administration.

pros: PTO; hybrid environment; good team and colleagues
cons: No raise in 5+ years benefits have gotten more expensive to maintain

pros: There were nice people for the most part
cons: Raises do not happen ever

pros: great community and exciting mission
cons: uncertain higher education landscape unsettling

pros: pays for 2 classes a semester
cons: not appreciated, does the work a full time employee would be doing

pros: Friendly staff, helps pay for 2 college courses a semester, great learning opportunity

review_title: Great colleagues and students; Awful treatment by administration
pros: Rider is a great place to work because of my colleagues and the students. Plus we have a lot of autonomy in how we run our classes and the service activities we choose to take on.
cons: The administration treats us like dirt. Faculty haven't had a salary increase in many years and our benefits keep getting cut. We lose money every year we work at the school. The administration would replace every tenure track professor with adjuncts if they could.

pros: The workload is not difficult
cons: Management is all over the place, it is unclear what people want, and there is no loyalty to the staff.

review_title: Great place for students to work

review_title: Ok place to work, but no security
pros: Friendly faculty, motivated students, easily accessible campus

pros: community, great coworkers, location, campus
cons: stress level, lack of work life balance

pros: My fellow co workers were great to work with and I loved the fact that we could all get stuff done as a team when we needed to and also were able to work on our own as much as possible as well. We were a well balanced team.
cons: The management was a little too fond of playing the favorites game. It was very obvious who they liked more than others. They would see several employees do the same things and certain ones could get away with it while other would be reprimanded. Even if it was a first time offense and I found that to be very unfair. They also underpaid me in my job area even though i have over 10yrs experience, buty would pay someone more who never did the job before

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros:
For faculty, reasonably-sized classes make it easy to get to know the students and make sure that they are understanding and retaining the information that you are sharing with them. It is small university in terms of enrollment. I believe there are approximately 3,000 full-time students. 

It is known for its strength in business, science, teaching and communication, to name some of the specialty areas. The student body is diverse with every race, nationality and religion represented so the discussion in the classroom environment is quite lively and stretches the thinking and background of all the students as well as the professors.
cons: No real downside. I was a part-time faculty member so I did not have the benefits that full-time faculty receive.

pros: Same as any university job. Good benefits. Sick and Vacation time is separate from PTO. Most holidays off.  Access to free college courses.
cons: Terrible upper management. I was downsized and laid off. Many facets of office and facility staff are on chopping block for outsourcing. Students with zero experience are being put in positions of middle management to allow upper management a a puppet to parrot their every whim.Board of Trustees compiled of unsavory business types. University is currently in legal debt to the tune of $10mil. Google Westminster Choir College sale to find out more.

pros: Steady job, decent starting wage, summer hours, tuition remission program,
cons: Board of Trustees have too much power, too many entitled tenured older professors, too many recent grads hired directly as managment, administration trying to force out regular employees and replace with cheap student labor, administration cries poor but spends big for their own personal gain. Maintenance employees have not had a raise in 5 years. Administration has looked into out sourcing maintenance and security.

pros: Great location and tuition program.
cons: If you do not hold a high level degree, management mistreats their employees.  Instead of bringing everyone together and be a team, I had noticed that many managers would mistreat subordinates due to their lower class, education and salary.  Such a shame.  Some managers do not care about their employees at all, shaming them for having families/children and missing out on work due to unforeseen circumstances, but the managers would take long vacations, come in to work hours late, take numerous hour lunches, but that was fine.  Shame on you Rider!!!

pros: It is a job where you get to interact with a lot of young people and some of those interactions can be very fulfilling.
cons:
No raises for the last 3 years, declining benefits (403b contribution dropped by 70% in Jul 2015), horrible systems, dated management philosophies and expectations that you do even more work (over normal working hours) for less pay and benefits.
I'm sure more people would complain about the things that go on at Rider (and the things long term employees get away with) but the HR office is feckless and seemingly completely engaged in protecting the university versus protecting the worker.

pros: You get to meet great people through all of the external events that are held on campus. Great boss and Auxiliary Services team staff.
cons: Lots of down time, can be boring  Must be willing to work in all kinds of weather. You have to be customer services oriented, otherwise all of the angry parents that show up to camps and tournaments will upset you.

review_title: Taught as an adjunct and the experience was great
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros: Taught a science class as an adjunct and the infrastructure and supports were excellent. The students were motivated and the pay was competitive with other institutions. As a smaller school they ran the class with about 8 students which never would have happened at a larger university
cons: The only real con for Rider is that they didn't hire me for a full-time faculty position. I would adjunct there again.

review_title: A typical, decent, comprehensive University focusing on business, education, and performing art esp. vocal music.
pros: Supportive, collegial, homey atmosphere.  It's easy to get to know people in other departments.   Number of adjuncts allowed is limited.  Strong union.
cons: Health benefits are dismal.   Unbalanced focus:  liberal arts and sciences are the poor cousins, existing mostly for service courses.  Strong union.

job_title: Adjunct Associate Professor in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros: Good pay friendly atmosphere good benefits for adjuncts; Union has been too successful;  great freedom to make the course your own
cons: Full-Time faculty is into intrigue; ethical climate is atrocious; never was there so much intrigue with so little at stake; currently in a financial crisis; student body somewhat ignorant and racist, ugly racist incident with fraternity in the 90's; fistfights in the cafeteria when Obama was elected.

review_title: Once a great place to work...
pros: Excellent faculty and the school provides a worthwhile education.  Tuition rates are competitive for students.  Excellent tuition remission program for eligible employees and their families.
cons: The school is in financial turmoil....has been for several years.  The impact on employees has been significant - cuts to benefits, salaries, hiring freezes.  Top administrators make high six figure salaries while under performing.  Not a great place to work.

pros: This place makes a HUGE difference for the students who attend.  Some faculty are incredibly dedicated and are truly outstanding teachers.
cons: Enrollment is down and in conjunction with financial management, this place could be going down the tubes in the next couple of years.  Union has stranglehold on academic leadership in a bad way.

pros: Flexible work, easygoing colleagues, tuition aid, a lot of chance to get along with the professors, close to downtown Princeton.
cons: Low salaries, workload is crazy at the beginning of the semesters but other times it can be boring, management is not very supportive to the employees.

pros: Great benefits, not a corporate environment, excellent at retaining employees, excellent time off in addition to already great time off - week off between Christmas and new years, great summer hours
cons: Rider is a great place to work if you have the opportunity, the things that weren't good for me had to do with me rather than Rider.

job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Lawrence, NJ
pros: An absolutely amazing job where you have great bosses and flexible hours. I get to showcase the school that I love
cons: There are no real cons to this job. It is a great place to work at to be all  of the time.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Princeton Junction, Mercer, NJ
pros: Pay and Opportunity to expand your horizons
cons: Political environment detracts from academic excellence.  There is no correlation between student and even peer reviews and opportunities.  It is all about who you know.

pros: Were not too many other student painters, occasional cookout for lunch
cons: Some of my higher ups that were not really higher ups were not the most respectful all the time

pros: Warm, welcoming environment. Friendly co-workers. Helpful support services.
cons: It's not really a "con," but the university could do a better job of making the adjuncts feel more connected and included in the day-to-day operations and activities on campus, especially those of us who teach night courses.

pros: Rider is on the rise with a sound strategic vision and growing enrollment. The student and faculty cultures are positive, energetic and collaborative.
cons: Facilities require updating. The school's financial situation is concerning but seems to be heading in the right direction.

job_title: Computer Lab Monitor in Lawrenceville, NJ
pros: Allow you do to your homework while on the job.
cons: Have to stay until 12am which is when the lab closes and it sucks if you have an 8 am class the next day.

review_title: Rider University is extremely well organized
pros: Only hires, and keeps, the most competent and qualified individuals for each individuals respective job
cons: Sometimes needs a few more people to be available in case of emergencies.

review_title: Very tiring and draining for little pay
